words.definition: A problem in code or execution that causes a program to malfunction or stop.
words.example: A syntax error prevents the code from running.
examples: The console displays error messages.
words.notes: Error handling is vital for robust apps.

words.definition: To record information about a program’s execution, usually for debugging or monitoring.
words.example: Log user actions for analytics.
examples: Use console.log to debug variables.
words.notes: Logging is essential for diagnostics.

words.definition: To check code for correctness, performance, or reliability by running it under controlled conditions.
words.example: Test all components before deployment.
examples: Write unit tests for each function.
words.notes: Testing prevents bugs in production.

words.definition: A test that checks the behavior of an individual function or component in isolation.
words.example: Write unit tests for each utility.
examples: Unit tests ensure functions work as expected.
words.notes: Unit testing is core to TDD.

words.definition: A test that checks how different parts of an application work together.
words.example: Integration tests cover component interactions.
examples: Run integration tests before release.
words.notes: Integration tests catch issues between modules.

words.definition: To analyze code for stylistic or programming errors using automated tools.
words.example: Lint your code to enforce style rules.
examples: ESLint is used for JavaScript linting.
words.notes: Linting improves code quality.

words.definition: To automatically arrange code according to style guidelines.
words.example: Format code with Prettier before committing.
examples: Formatting keeps code consistent.
words.notes: Formatting is often automated.

words.definition: To compile, bundle, and optimize source code for deployment.
words.example: Run npm run build to generate the production app.
examples: The build process creates optimized files.
words.notes: Build steps are defined in Next.js and React.

words.definition: To publish an application to a server or hosting platform for users to access.
words.example: Deploy the site to Vercel or Netlify.
examples: Deployment makes the app live online.
words.notes: Deployment is the final step in development.

words.definition: A single file or set of files created by combining and optimizing source code for deployment.
words.example: The JavaScript bundle loads all app code.
examples: Bundles reduce the number of HTTP requests.
words.notes: Bundling is handled by Webpack or Vite.

words.definition: Describes files or content that do not change at runtime and can be served directly.
words.example: Static assets include images and fonts.
examples: Static generation pre-builds pages for speed.
words.notes: Next.js supports static site generation.

words.definition: Describes content or code that can change at runtime, often in response to user input or data.
words.example: Dynamic routes generate pages on demand.
examples: Dynamic imports load code as needed.
words.notes: Dynamic rendering is used for personalized content.

words.definition: Server-Side Rendering, a technique where pages are rendered on the server and sent to the client.
words.example: SSR improves SEO and initial load speed.
examples: Next.js supports SSR for dynamic content.
words.notes: SSR is a core feature of Next.js.

words.definition: Static Site Generation, a method where pages are pre-rendered at build time for fast delivery.
words.example: SSG is ideal for blogs and documentation.
examples: Next.js uses SSG for static pages.
words.notes: SSG is fast and cacheable.

words.definition: A serverless function in Next.js that handles backend logic and HTTP requests.
words.example: Create an API route for form submissions.
examples: API routes are defined in the /pages/api directory.
words.notes: API routes enable full-stack apps in Next.js.

words.definition: A specific URL where an API can be accessed by clients.
words.example: POST requests are sent to the /api/submit endpoint.
examples: Endpoints define how clients interact with the server.
words.notes: Endpoints are the entry points for APIs.

words.definition: Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked APIs.
words.example: REST APIs use HTTP methods like GET and POST.
examples: REST is common for web APIs.
words.notes: RESTful APIs are stateless.

words.definition: Software that sits between the request and response in a server, enabling tasks like authentication or logging.
words.example: Use middleware to check authentication on API routes.
examples: Middleware can modify requests and responses.
words.notes: Next.js supports middleware for edge logic.

words.definition: The process in which client-side JavaScript takes over a server-rendered HTML page and makes it interactive.
words.example: Next.js uses hydration to enable dynamic behavior after SSR.
examples: Hydration bridges static markup and interactive UI.
words.notes: Key to seamless SSR/CSR transitions.

words.definition: The process by which React updates the DOM by comparing the new virtual DOM with the previous one and applying minimal changes.
words.example: Reconciliation ensures efficient UI updates.
examples: React's diffing algorithm handles reconciliation.
words.notes: Optimizes UI performance.

words.definition: A lightweight copy of the real DOM used by React to optimize UI updates.
words.example: The virtual DOM improves rendering speed.
examples: React computes changes in the virtual DOM before updating the real DOM.
words.notes: Central to React's efficiency.

words.definition: To generate and display UI elements based on code and data.
words.example: React components render UI from props and state.
examples: The render function returns JSX.
words.notes: Rendering is core to React and Next.js.

words.definition: Describes code or operations that run in the user's browser rather than on the server.
words.example: Client-side rendering enables fast UI updates.
examples: Client-side logic handles user interactions.
words.notes: CSR is common in SPAs.

words.definition: Describes code or operations that run on a web server before being sent to the client.
words.example: Server-side rendering improves SEO.
examples: Next.js supports server-side data fetching.
words.notes: SSR is a Next.js feature.

words.definition: Client-Side Rendering, where UI is rendered in the browser using JavaScript.
words.example: CSR enables fast navigation without page reloads.
examples: CSR is standard in React SPAs.
words.notes: CSR is fast but less SEO-friendly.

words.definition: Incremental Static Regeneration, a Next.js feature that updates static pages after deployment without rebuilding the whole site.
words.example: ISR allows for real-time content updates.
examples: ISR combines SSG speed with dynamic content.
words.notes: Unique to Next.js.

words.definition: A function that runs before a request is completed, used for tasks like authentication, redirects, or logging in Next.js.
words.example: Middleware checks user authentication on every request.
examples: Middleware can rewrite URLs or set headers.
words.notes: Middleware runs at the edge in Next.js.

words.definition: The arrangement of UI components on a page, often managed with CSS or Tailwind.
words.example: The layout component wraps all pages.
examples: Tailwind utilities help build responsive layouts.
words.notes: Layout is key to good UX.

words.definition: Describes a UI that adapts to different screen sizes and devices.
words.example: Responsive design is essential for mobile users.
examples: Tailwind makes responsive layouts easy.
words.notes: Responsive UIs are standard in modern web dev.

words.definition: A defined screen width at which the layout or styles change to adapt to different devices.
words.example: Tailwind uses breakpoints for responsive design.
examples: Set breakpoints for mobile, tablet, and desktop.
words.notes: Breakpoints drive adaptive styling.

words.definition: A set of design tokens and styles that define the look and feel of an application.
words.example: Switch between light and dark themes.
examples: Tailwind configures custom themes easily.
words.notes: Themes are managed in Tailwind config.

words.definition: A UI theme that uses dark backgrounds and light text for reduced eye strain.
words.example: Enable dark mode for better nighttime viewing.
examples: Tailwind supports dark mode out of the box.
words.notes: Dark mode is a popular accessibility feature.

words.definition: A methodology for creating design systems by breaking interfaces into small, reusable pieces (atoms, molecules, organisms).
words.example: Atomic design helps build scalable UIs.
examples: Buttons and inputs are atoms in atomic design.
words.notes: Atomic design is used in modern UI libraries.

words.definition: Describes code or components that can be used in multiple places without modification.
words.example: Reusable components speed up development.
examples: Atomic design encourages reusability.
words.notes: Reusable code is easier to maintain.

words.definition: A build optimization technique that removes unused code from the final bundle.
words.example: Tree shaking reduces bundle size.
examples: Webpack and Vite support tree shaking.
words.notes: Tree shaking is key for performance.

words.definition: A development feature that updates the UI instantly when code changes, without a full page reload.
words.example: Hot reload speeds up development feedback.
examples: Next.js and React support hot reload.
words.notes: Hot reload improves developer experience.
